item.title: #DeFi only makes sense with private data. This is infeasible on Ethereum, but trivial on $MINA.

item.content:encoded:
#DeFi only makes sense with private data. This is infeasible on Ethereum, but trivial on $MINA.

Zero-Knowledge will lead to mass adoption of #DeFi, enabling its Cambrian explosion.

Of course, you can also bridge $MINA to Ethereum. This is by design.

Big things are coming.

item.title: Generally accepted principles of corporate accounting are:
item.description: Generally accepted principles of corporate accounting are: - Historical cost - asset value is recorded at book/acquisition value - Prudence/Conservatism - decrease the asset value in the balanceâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
Generally accepted principles of corporate accounting are:

- Historical cost - asset value is recorded at book/acquisition value
- Prudence/Conservatism - decrease the asset value in the balance sheet if it has fallen in value. Unrealized gains are ignored

ğŸ‡¯ğŸ‡µBOJ abides by them
item.author: illya.gerasymchuk.social@gmail.com (Illya Gerasymchuk)

1ï¸âƒ£ Yen bonds at amortized cost

item.title: Basis/carry yield in expiring futures â‰ˆ funding rate in perpetual futures
item.description: Basis/carry yield in expiring futures â‰ˆ funding rate in perpetual futures Both converge futures price with spot via an arbitrage incentive - long undervalued, short overvalued Profits are realizedâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
Basis/carry yield in expiring futures â‰ˆ funding rate in perpetual futures

Both converge futures price with spot via an arbitrage incentive - long undervalued, short overvalued

Profits are realized once at expiry for basis, and periodically for funding rate (e.g. every 8h)

item.title: Catastrophe bonds (cat bonds) work by having an investor pool deposit 100% of collateral and earnâ€¦
item.description: Catastrophe bonds (cat bonds) work by having an investor pool deposit 100% of collateral and earn â‰ˆrisk free rate + premium paid by the insured If the covered event occurs, investors lose aâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
Catastrophe bonds (cat bonds) work by having an investor pool deposit 100% of collateral and earn â‰ˆrisk free rate + premium paid by the insured

If the covered event occurs, investors lose a proportionate part of their principal, as the insured gets repaid from the collateral

item.content:encoded:
UNâ€™s Model Double Taxation Convention has a clear key benefit over OCEDâ€™s

since UNâ€™s model gives more taxing rights for the source state - itâ€™s the one that makes sense for developing economies

imagine a developed nation benefiting from cheaper labor in the source state - who created the workforce in the first place, and having their tax base eroded in favor of resident state

so the resident state would get double benefit:

1ï¸âƒ£ cheaper labor
2ï¸âƒ£ higher tax income for the government

on the other hand you could argue for OCEDâ€™s model favoring a higher volume of investment, thus effectively distributing more wages throughout the economy. this channels the funds more directly to the consumers, which would end up increasing their purchasing power more than if it had to go through the government first

but then again, you must remember the global market is NOT a free market economy. existing legislation overall favors more developed countries, so protective measures for developing countries in the international tax law may make a lot of sense

item.content:encoded:
reverse repurchase agreement is just the other side (seller) side of a repurchase agreement (buyer)

repurchaser provides collateral and receives a loan

reverse repurchaser receives the collateral and issues a loan

at maturity the repurchaser repurchases the collateral

item.content:encoded:
repurchase agreements are almost always over-collateralized

the borrower undervalues the collateral by a percentage (haircut) - this is a buffer against price volatility

the purchase and repurchase price are computed over the post-haircut value

item.title: so if you have a UST bond worth $100:
item.description: so if you have a UST bond worth $100: lender applies a haircut (e.g. 2%) - 100*(1-0.02)=$98 lender sets a repurchase price (e.g. $98.013) so you use your $100 bond to get a $98 loan, for which youâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
so if you have a UST bond worth $100:

lender applies a haircut (e.g. 2%) - 100*(1-0.02)=$98
lender sets a repurchase price (e.g. $98.013)

so you use your $100 bond to get a $98 loan, for which you must repay with a fee (interest) $98.013

if you have a US bond and you need cash, your options are:
